               * Checks that the replica location is an hdfs location. This will delete replica data whether it is been replicated
          
          
            
               * Checks that the replica location is an hdfs location. This will delete replica data whether it has been replicated
supportsDeletion -> maybe more generic -> supportsSchemas (like copierFactory) or supportsDataManipulation()??

nodes.bodyText: These need to go, these beans should be stateless.
Interface on left hand side please.
interface DefaultDataManipulationClientFactoryManager -> DataManipulationClientFactoryManager

interface DefaultDataManipulationClientFactoryManager -> DataManipulationClientFactoryManager
and yes I know then you can't use your handy with methods anymore but that's a good thing :)
I think this code will become easier if you get the Factory here and not the manager.

use com.hotels.hcommon.hive.metastore.iterator.PartitionIterator please (https://github.com/HotelsDotCom/hcommon-hive-metastore) there might be many partitions pulling them all out might not scale well
should be the interface and probably needs to be the factory
remove try catch, it does't add anything. You're swallowing the exception this way, just let it be thrown, calling class is responsible for deciding what to do with it.
yeah thats a good point. Might be a good idea to include that then
See my comment in the interface this should return a Factory not the client.

Having looked through this I'm not sure whether we need to expose the term "client". Could we just call it a Data Manipulator? Feels more generic to me. Then this property would become data-manipulator-factory-class. Obviously impacts on the rest of the doc so I won't comment again on this below. What do others think?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -328,6 +328,7 @@ If data is being replicated to HDFS then Circus Train will use DistCp to copy th
             skip-crc: false
             ssl-configuration-file: /foo/bar/ssl-config
             copier-factory-class: com.hotels.bdp.circustrain.distcpcopier.DistCpCopier
+            client-manipulation-factory-class: com.hotels.bdp.circustrain.distcpcopier.HdfsDataManipulationClientFactory

nodes.bodyText: Yeah that works for me. Think the name came from starting out with copying from s3->s3 and needing an s3client to "manipulate the data". Happy to change to this, it reads nicer.

nodes.bodyText: This does more than just check, it also performs the cleanup. Perhaps rename to cleanupReplicaIfRequired. Or maybe better move the if (replicationMode == FULL_OVERWRITE) { up to where it was before and then call this method cleanupReplica as it only applies to that mode.
Wouldn't it be better to move this to line 448? There's no need to create a client unless we get that far.
Should we log e here too so we know why?

should't we just throw the exception and stop?
We haven't deleted the existing one so writing again will probably fail anyway.
How is this different to dropTable now? If we're always going to remove the params in that method then I'm not sure we need this one anymore?

Its technically no different, but it gets the table object and passes that into the dropTable method. I added the dropTable method and made it take in a table object because otherwise when dropTableAndData is called it would get the table object, delete partition info, then call dropTable which will get the table object again and then drop it. So by doing it this way it reduces the number of times that client.getTable is called.

Are we OK with not doing the whole partition iterator trick here? I guess for most of this type of table they're generally not very big so it's unlikely this will return tens of thousands of partitions and run out of memory like we've had in other parts of the code so it's probably fine.

Do you mean the hcommon PartitionIterator trick? b/c if so then it does use that in the getPartitionLocations method at the bottom of the class.
PartitionIterator partitionIterator = new PartitionIterator(client, table, BATCH_SIZE);
Yes this is not useful to log and might even be confusing.

At the moment this will stop if one of the partitions couldn't be dropped. Wouldn't it be better to put the try/catch around line 124 so it can try each location? And then basically do an AND on the booleans returned so if any one is false then the method returns false.

I think we should log on line 124 before doing the delete which location we're trying to delete and then let the exception bubble up. Why try all of them if 1 fails and 99 succeeds shouldn't we stop the replication?
This feature is about deleting existing table/data + replication if one part of this fails the whole thing should fail?
OK, as long as the approach is consistent, I'm fine with it being "as soon as anything goes wrong, ABORT AND FAIL!"
Then this message can log the actual partition location which will be more meaningful (and also log the exception)
Why do we need this?

Ah OK, so we do use the iterator but we then add them all to a list so this could still OOM. I think it's alright to do this for now but the "proper" way would be to use the iterator, not an intermediate collection.
let's fix this please, we've hit this in the past, it's better to make this resistant now since we're testing it actively and actually have it fresh in our heads.

Log the exception.
Also, should we swallow all these exceptions with warnings or should we throw them and fail the replication?
I don't mind. It technically wont affect the replication, but you could end up with a lot of orphaned data which wont be cleaned up.

I think all exceptions in this class except ones we can recover from should be thrown and stop the replication. Logging them serves little purpose, no one is going to look through the log if the end replication reports OK. If the purpose is alerting the user to manually clean up, best to just fail. If this becomes unfeasible e.g. lots of failures we can build retry mechanics etc.. but out of scope now.
You can do this on line 39
similar for lines 56, 59

Might be cleaner to have a small enum with the types S3_S3, S3_MAPREDUCE and HDFS and then have one method called something like setManipulatorType. You could also pass the type in to the constructor and then not need this extra method.
Static import Assert.
Is this checking anything other than the logic you've put in the test class itself? I don't think so?

Not really, just checking that it will go through the list of factories, check if the replication is supported and returns the right one. And that it returns the one specified in the copier options (if any).
If you're mocking this (line 64) then why are you doing this?
You could put this in a for loop from 1-11, would remove a few lines of code.
You can do this in one line above.
Ditto and below etc.
Same as in other test.
etc.
Please document the "may throw an error" part using the standard Javadoc for exceptions thrown.

nodes.bodyText: What does this line do? The result isn't being assigned to anything - is it needed?
I think this and the changes below are much clearer now, also better using the partition iterator properly, nice.
Woah, what's up with those double semi-colons?!?!? Crrraazzyy, they need to GO! (and below)
😱 copy-paste fail!!!
I'd prefer using assertEquals here, you get a better error message from JUnit if this fails rather than just "wasn't true".
Looks like assertEquals is deprecated!
Are you sure? We use it all over the show, what does it suggest you use instead in the deprecation warning?
The method assertEquals(Object, Object) from the type Assert is deprecated. Add @SuppressWarnings 'deprecation' to 's3ManipulatorReturnedForS3S3Copy()'
assertEquals(S3_S3, ((TestDataManipulatorFactory) clientFactory).getType()); looks OK to me? I don't see a warning in Eclipse?
hmm yeah that works for me too. It's when I do Assert.assertEquals.. it has an issue. Weird. Will change them 👍🏻
Which Assert class do you import when you do that? My guess is you're by mistake pulling in an old Junit Assert class where everything is deprecated.
ahh yeah looks like it, the one with everything deprecated is inside junit.framework but the Assert class that works is in org.junit.
Ditto (and etc. below)
Does this need to be public?
Can this be private?
